awd_abstract_narration:
This research project investigates probability questions arising in the study of population dynamics and genealogies with multi-species interactions. The latter study is a key to understanding biodiversity in ecosystems, epidemiological spread, heterogeneity of cancer tumors, and the mechanisms underlying many complex systems in nature. This project is the first step towards the development of more refined models that not only address standing questions in virology and ecology, but also catalyze the generation of new mathematical methods. The involvement of undergraduate students in stochastic analysis and simulations will enhance their ability to work at the interface between probability and applied sciences. 

The principal investigator aims to design various spatial stochastic models, including nonstandard interacting particle systems, interacting superprocesses, and coupled stochastic partial differential equations on general metric graphs, to contribute to a deeper understanding of the effect of spatial structures and randomness on various population dynamics and their genealogies in different scales of observation. New challenges arise in the study of well-posedness and time asymptotic properties of these models. The project will focus on two research directions.
(i) Explore new connections among these models. Outcomes of this research are expected to include scaling limit theorems and duality formulas that rigorously justify the new connections.
(ii) Study the long-time behavior of these spatial stochastic models. New probabilistic methods will be developed to compute quantities of interest, such as the asymptotic shape of competition outcome and the propagation speeds of travelling waves on networks.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The PI has developed probabilistic tools for population models with multi-species interactions. The results and methods are broad and cut across several mathematical areas and applied disciplines. The major outcome of this work that impacts mathematics is the rigorous connection between stochastic models of different scales, which offers deeper insight into how stochastic partial differential equations (SPDE) arise from discrete systems, as well as duality relations between these SPDE and branching-coalescing particle systems that enables the study of long-time behaviors of these systems. The PI discovered a critical growth rate and obtained a formula of asymptotic speed for reaction-diffusion equations on random regular trees. These works justify that SPDE on graphs are robust against microscopic perturbations, and lay down important ground work that enable in-depth analysis of reaction-diffusion type SPDE. 

The PI's mathematical work gives rigorous justification to some conjectures from physics and biology. The numerical schemes developed in this work provide a rigorous foundation for the numerical computation and simulations of stochastic models. This project has enhanced existing models and the analysis of population dynamics involving multi-species interactions and environmental fluctuations, which leads to a deeper understanding of complex spatial systems and potential biomedical applications. This project benefits researchers at the graduate and undergraduate levels, linking how applied scientists and mathematicians are trained.
